file_name: OTISWORLDWIDECORP_04_03_2020-EX-10.4-INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY AGREEMENT by and among UNITED TECHNOLOGIES CORPORATION, OTIS WORLDWIDE CORPORATION and CARRIER ~1.txt

perturbation.original_text: "Assignee Group" shall mean one of the UTC Group, the Otis Group, or the Carrier Group of which an Assignee Party is a member. "Assignee Party" shall mean the Party, as the context requires, other than the Assignor Party, to whom Intellectual Property Rights are assigned from the Assignor Party pursuant to the terms hereof.
perturbation.changed_text: "Assignee Group" shall mean one of the UTC Group, the Otis Group, or the Carrier Group of which an Assignee Party is a member. "Recipient" shall mean the Party, as the context requires, other than the Assignor Party, to whom Intellectual Property Rights are assigned from the Assignor Party pursuant to the terms hereof.
perturbation.explanation: The term 'Assignee Party' is replaced with 'Recipient'. Although context implies they are the same, failing to explicitly define Recipient creates ambiguity and introduces inconsistency. This leads to a contradiction because, in other sections of the contract, 'Assignee Party' is used as the main identifier, thus disrupting uniformity.

perturbation.original_text: Subject to Section 3.2, each Assignor Party, on behalf of itself and the other members of the Assignor Group, hereby irrevocably assigns to the applicable Assignee Party, and agrees to irrevocably assign to the applicable Assignee Party, all of its and the other members of the Assignor Group's rights, title and interest in and to any and all Intellectual Property Rights owned by the Assignor Party or another member of the Assignor Group that meets one or more of the following descriptions: (a) the Intellectual Property Rights are Requester Foreground IPR conceived or created in the course of services concerning which the Assignee Party or another member of the Assignee Group was the Requester, and the Assignor Party or another member of the Assignor Group was the Performer; or (b) the Intellectual Property Rights are Performer Foreground-Delivered IPR conceived or created in the course of services concerning which the Assignee Party or another member of the Assignee Group was the Requester, and the Assignor Party or another member of the Assignor Group was the Performer; or
perturbation.changed_text: Subject to Section 3.2, each Assignor Party, on behalf of itself and the other members of the Assignor Group, hereby irrevocably assigns to the applicable Assignee Party, and agrees to irrevocably assign to the applicable Assignee Party, all of its and the other members of the Assignor Group's rights, title and interest in and to any and all Intellectual Property Rights owned by the Assignor Party or another member of the Assignor Group that meets one or more of the following descriptions: (a) the Intellectual Property Rights are Requester Foreground IPR conceived or created in the course of services concerning which the Receiver or another member of the Assignee Group was the Requester, and the Assignor Party or another member of the Assignor Group was the Performer; or (b) the Intellectual Property Rights are Performer Foreground-Delivered IPR conceived or created in the course of services concerning which the Assignee Party or another member of the Assignee Group was the Requester, and the Assignor Party or another member of the Assignor Group was the Performer; or
perturbation.explanation: In Section 2.1.1, the term 'Assignee Party' is changed to 'Receiver' in subsection (a). This change introduces confusion because the document now refers to the same entity in two different ways, creating a contradiction. It is unclear if 'Receiver' and 'Assignee Party' have different obligations.

perturbation.original_text: "Confidential Information" shall have the meaning defined in Section 6.2.
perturbation.changed_text: "Sensitive Data" shall have the meaning defined in Section 6.2.
perturbation.explanation: Changing 'Confidential Information' to 'Sensitive Data' in the definition section, while Section 6.2 still defines 'Confidential Information,' creates a fundamental conflict. The contract now lacks a clear definition for 'Confidential Information' but continues to use it, making its enforcement uncertain.
